Claude Parent

452 words written on Sat, Apr 6 2019

Twelve Subversive Acts to Dodge the System

  1. Open the Imaginary
  2. Operate in Illusion
  3. Dislodge the Immobile
  4. Think Continuity
  5. Surf on the Surface
  6. Live in Obliqueness
  7. Destabilize
  8. Use the Fall
  9. Fracture
  10. Practice Inversion
  11. Orchestrate Conflict
  12. Limit Without Closing

Claude Parent‚Äôs Manifesto, 2001

Consider how boring it is within our homes. The kid stays in the assigned kid‚Äôs room while the grown-up sits on an inherited couch in another room. We‚Äôre completely overfurnished. What would it be like on the other hand, if space were understood more playfully, more free, if movement and being in a space also could mean climbing, reclining, sliding?‚Äù What would happen, Parent asked, if you make people group in ways different to those required by the given social parameters of ‚Äúchair‚Äù, ‚Äútable‚Äù, ‚Äúsofa‚Äù, ‚Äúbed‚Äù, etc? Can furnitureless architecture affect dynamics between people? Claude Parent explored this question ‚Äì and in so doing became one of the most important social utopians in the modern history of architecture.

In 1970, he installed an artificial landscape made of slopes in the French pavilion at the Venice Biennale. He renovated his house. All furniture was eliminated and instead, ramps and sloped surfaces were built in. A photograph from that time shows Parent with family and guests: like a guru of unfurnished existence, he sits on one of these slopes while the others squat, lounge and recline around him as if they were the deconstructed return of the school of athens. it‚Äôs hard to tell what is a wall and what is a ceiling, to distinguish what is up from what is down. Through this dissolution of categories and order systems, Parent wanted to discover a new freedom.

Commercially, Parent‚Äôs new living world was no success. Those who loved his ‚Äúoblique‚Äù architecture the most‚Äìchildren‚Äìcouldn‚Äôt afford it. In the foreword to his recently published complete works, Parent‚Äôs daughter writes, ‚ÄúI ran with my dog over ramps and let marbles roll down ‚Äì my parents had banned all furniture from the house, there were hardly any doors, you laid on plateaus and in caverns‚Ä¶After the day when the workmen came to install the ramps, the extraordinary became everyday life‚Ä¶At points there were soft spots embedded in the ramps that you couldn‚Äôt see‚Äìvisitors would often scream in terror when they stepped on such a spot.‚Äù

Parent was celebrated as a hero of deconstruction, as one of the first to implement Derrida‚Äôs theory ‚Äì to take an established system and not destroy it, but rather to take it apart and put it back together in a new, playful, less hierarchical way ‚Äì in the field of construction.
